bullets.text: A linear equation with n variables in standard form: $a_1 x_1 + a_2 x_2 + \dots + a_n x_n = b$. $a_i$ are coefficients, $b$ is the constant.
formulas: $a_1 x_1 + a_2 x_2 + \dots + a_n x_n = b$

bullets.text: A linear system (or system of linear equations) is a finite set of linear equations.
A linear system is homogeneous if all constants $b_i$ are 0.
A linear system is inconsistent if it has no solutions. It is consistent otherwise.
The general solution to a linear system captures all possible solutions.
Augmented Matrix: A matrix representing a linear system, with coefficients on the left and constants on the right of a vertical bar.
Row-Echelon Form (REF):
1. Zero rows are at the bottom.
2. Leading entries move to the right as rows go down.
Pivot Column: A column containing a leading entry in REF.
Reduced Row-Echelon Form (RREF): A matrix in REF where:
3. Leading entries are 1.
4. Entries above and below leading entries in pivot columns are 0.
Row Equivalent Matrices: Matrices that can be transformed into each other via elementary row operations.
1. Exchanging two rows: $R_i \leftrightarrow R_j$
2. Adding a multiple of a row to another: $R_i + cR_j$, $c \in \mathbb{R}$
3. Multiplying a row by a nonzero constant: $aR_j$, $a \neq 0$
Performing elementary row operations preserves the solutions of a linear system.
Each elementary row operation has a reverse operation.
Gaussian Elimination: Reduces an augmented matrix to Row-Echelon Form (REF).
Gauss-Jordan Elimination: Reduces an augmented matrix to Reduced Row-Echelon Form (RREF).
Steps for Gaussian Elimination:
1. Locate the leftmost column with nonzero entries.
2. Swap rows to bring a nonzero entry to the top of this column.
3. Use row operations to make entries below the leading entry zero.
4. Repeat steps 1-3 for the submatrix below the current leading entry.
Steps for Gauss-Jordan Elimination (after REF):
5. Multiply rows to make all leading entries 1.
6. Use row operations to make entries above leading entries zero.
If the augmented matrix is in REF, use back-substitution.
If the augmented matrix is in RREF, read off solutions directly.
Inconsistent System: If the last column of the augmented matrix in REF/RREF is a pivot column.
Assign parameters to variables corresponding to non-pivot columns in the LHS of the augmented matrix.
Number of parameters = Number of non-pivot columns.
Example (RREF): $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 2 \ 0 & 1 & 1 & -1 & 3 \ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \ \end{pmatrix}$. Non-pivot columns: 3, 4. Let $x_3=s, x_4=t$. Then $x_1=2-s, x_2=3-s+t$.
Example (REF): $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 2 & 11 \ 0 & 1 & -1 & 7 \ 0 & 0 & 1 & -1 \ \end{pmatrix}$. Back-substitution: $x_3=-1$, $x_2=7-(-1)=6$, $x_1=11-6+2(-1)=3$. Unique solution.
Example (REF with parameters): $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 & -1 & 2 \ 0 & 0 & 1 & -1 & 0 & 4 \ \end{pmatrix}$. Non-pivot columns: 1, 4. Let $x_1=s, x_4=t$. Then $x_5=4, x_3=-1+t, x_2=2+x_5=6$.
A linear system can have no solution, a unique solution, or infinitely many solutions.
2 Variables: No solution (parallel distinct lines), unique solution (intersecting lines), infinite solutions (coincident lines).
3 Variables: No solution (planes don't intersect), unique solution (planes intersect at a point), 1 parameter (planes intersect along a line), 2 parameters (planes coincide).
The number of pivot columns of R is equal to the number of nonzero rows of R (if R is in REF/RREF).
The number of non-pivot columns of R is equal to the number of zero rows in R (if R is in REF/RREF).
Multiplying a row by 0 can change the solution set of a linear system.
The order of row operations matters (they do not commute).
